title: Thesis award from the Swedish Competition Authority
text: I’m proud to announce that the masters thesis I coauthored placed second in the Swedish Competition Authority’s thesis competition. The SCA published the thesis, their motivation, and the interview.

title: My favorite open source tools
text:
I use R professionally in my daily work, but I have also obtained advanced knowledge of R via an advanced course in R, personal projects, and reading various books from The Big Book of R.
Specifically, I have used R to:

Conduct econometric estimations such as: OLS, GMM, Instrument variables estimations, and Merger simulations.
Manage complex data structures by working with nested data.
Clean data.
Create interactive command line interface applications to speed up manual tasks and learn new concepts.
Working with various application programming interface to automate workflows.

title: My favorite open source tools
text:
Git
I am experienced using Git for professional, academic, and personal projects. I primarily use the Pro Git book for learning more about Git. Since I prefer managing most things via a command line interface, and also use Git at the command line, I am able to complete more advanced git tasks rapidly.

title: My favorite open source tools
text:
Quarto
I am skilled using Quarto to create reports, presentations, websites, and books. Quarto enables me to automate tasks to speed up the writing process and develop more reproducible reports.

title: My favorite open source tools
text:
Shell
I prefer to manage most things via the command line. I use GNU/Linux on my personal machines and have used a wide variety of shells such as bash, fish, and mksh on them. I have also some experience using PowerShell on Windows machines. I use shell to manage files, script smaller repetitive tasks, and for smaller data exploration tasks.

title: Finns det en euroeffekt på handeln?
text:
Link to thesis
This Bachelor thesis’s purpose was to clarify recent questions on the euro effect, the effect that says that two countries who share the euro will trade more with each other, compared to countries that do not share the euro. Some authors have suggested that the euro effect in recent years has been significantly weaker than earlier studies have suggested. In recent years most studies conducted have used different types of simulation models to assess the effects of the euro, however this thesis uses the gravity model. The results are that the euro effect probably is stronger than ever.

title: How have the sanctions against Russia and their counter sanctions affected the Russian trade?
text:
Link to thesis
Economic sanctions are prevalent in the modern world as an alternative to war, instead aiming to maim economic growth and power by hindering trade. In recent times, sanctions have been imposed against many countries, Russia being one of them. Often seen as a response to questionable political and economic acts. The western countries and the UN being the main actors behind recent sanctions have faced relatively small negative effects of their imposed sanctions. The receiving countries however, often faced large consequences. With this thesis we aim to explain how Russia was affected and possibly still is affected by the sanctions imposed by the EU, the US, and their own counter sanctions. Searching for patterns to see if trade was diverted and if the sanctions have had lasting effects in a longer term. To research the question, we use descriptive statistics and regression analysis to explain and predict the effects over time. Our conclusions are that sanctions had a great immediate impact on trade. In the first year a decrease of up to 31.75% in bilateral trade between Russia and the EU and US was observed. As time passed, all parties significantly diverted their trade to a degree. The initial trade diversion of Russia being 42.48% in the first year

title: Medical Markup: A Check-Up on the Quality-Competition in Primary Care
text:
Link to thesis
We show that quality-competition among private firms in the Swedish primary care have worsened during the last 15 years. As a result, public funds turn into profits, rather than quality care for patients. Our interpretation is that providers have not increased their (cost of) quality at the same rate as the compensation has increased. We measure the intensity of quality-competition with markups, which we retrieve from a production function, as De Loecker and Warzynski (2012). Since this is the first application of this methodology to estimate quality competition, we adapt the method by including quality in the Ackerberg, Caves, and Frazer (2015) two-stage estimator to control for time-variant unobserved firm quality and productivity.

title: About
text:
I am an quantitative analyst who helps clients with analyzes related to competition economics. I enjoy solving quantitative problems and automating “boring tasks” using my in-depth knowledge of statistical programming languages and other open source tools.
I have a Master’s degree in economics, where the thesis I co-authored about competition in the Swedish primary care sector received an award by the Swedish competition authority. During my studies, I took courses within applied microeconomics, industrial organization, econometrics, and statistical programming, which gave me an in-depth theoretical understanding of markets and the quantitative tools used to analyze them.
